Experience: Leading a research group of graduate and undergraduate students to explore energy-efficient parallel computer architecture for both high-performance and embedded applications. Using a vertically integrated research methodology that involves rethinking the programming, runtimes, compilers, instruction sets, microarchitecture, and VLSI implementation of future computing systems. Current projects focus on: programmable accelerator-based architectures; general-purpose graphics processing unit (GPGPU) architecture; algorithm and data-structure hardware specialization; architecture and circuit co-design for integrated voltage regulation; and Python-based frameworks to enable more productive computer architecture research methodologies.

Active member of the architecture group which developed new manycore architectures to efficiently integrate hundreds of cores onto a single chip. Reviewer for the patterns group which worked on new design patterns for parallel programming.

Vector-Thread Architectures: Vector-threading (VT) combines the area and energy efficiency of vector architectures with the flexibility of multithreaded execution. Invented new techniques for integrating vector memory accesses into a traditional cache hierarchy. Helped design and implement the Scale VT Processor, a 0.18um ASIC prototype for embedded applications. Our later work studied techniques for simplifying VT architectures through a unified control-/micro-thread instruction set, a microarchitecture based on minimal changes to a standard vector-SIMD implementation, and an explicitly data-parallel C++ programming methodology.

Chip-Level Nanophotonic Interconnect Networks: Researched network architectures that leverage monolithic silicon photonics to improve performance and energy-efficiency of on-chip networks, processor-to-DRAM networks, and DRAM memory channel networks. Proposed new physical network layouts that decrease total optical and thermal-tuning power requirements. Implemented a detailed microarchitectural network simulator for performance studies. Collaborated with photonic circuit and device researchers at MIT to both understand the technology as well as influence device design based on system considerations.

Roger and Joelle Burnell Chair in Integrated Health and Technology

HealthRhythms makes it easy to measure and care for everyone’s mental health. By seamlessly gathering data about everyday behaviors and routines (our “social rhythms”), HealthRhythms provides a more comprehensive and clinically grounded understanding of mental wellbeing. Our solution leverages deep machine learning and predictive analytics to create novel health assessments and just-in-time personalized interventions that improve the care delivery experience for patients, health plans, payers and research organizations. HealthRhythms was founded by a unique team of mental health care pioneers and information scientists at the forefront of health sensing. For more information visit us at www.healthrhythms.com.
Directing People-Aware Computing Group @ Cornell and professing about Ubiquitous Computing

I direct the People-Aware Computing group at Cornell University. Along with my group of amazing team, I is working on inventing the future of technology-assisted wellbeing. My primary interests involve building novel wearables and mobile systems for capturing and influencing everyday human behaviors. I received her Ph.D. degree from the Media Laboratory at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT). As part of my doctoral work, she created the sociometer and conducted the first experiment that uses mobile sensors to model social networks, which led to a new field of research referred to as Reality Mining. I  am a recipient of MIT Technology Review TR35 award, an NSF Career Award, a TED fellowship, and a Kavli Fellowship.
